text: The only situation where \( m^3 \equiv 1 \pmod{3} \) is when \( m \equiv 1 \pmod{3} \).

class-2-reason: This sentence summarizes the conclusion from the analysis of all possible m modulo 3 residues, giving a logical deduction.

text: Thus, for \( m^3 = 3n^2 + 3n + 7 \), \( m \) must be of the form \( m \equiv 1 \pmod{3} \).

class-2-reason: Here the implications are drawn that m must have a certain form, based strictly on the above deduction; deducing a constraint from established results.

text: This means \( 3n^2 + 3n + 7 \equiv 1 \pmod{2} \), implying that any integer cube \( m^3 \) is odd.
